title-group.article-title: Nonlinear dynamical analysis and parameters optimization of four semi-active on-off dynamic vibration absorbers

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shijiazhuang Tiedao University, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Yong-Jun Shen, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Shijiazhuang Tiedao University, No. 17 Bei Erhuan Dong Road, Shijiazhuang, Hebei Province 050043, People’s Republic of China Email: shenyongjun@126.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper the averaging method is used to research the approximately analytical solution of a semi-active on-off dynamic vibration absorber (DVA). At first the approximately analytical solutions for the two existing semi-active on-off DVAs, named as velocity-velocity based ground-hook control and displacement- velocity based ground-hook control, are established by the averaging method. Then two other new semi-active on-off DVAs, named as velocity-displacement based ground-hook control and displacement-displacement based ground-hook control, are presented for the first time in this paper and also researched analytically. Moreover, all the optimal parameters of the four semi-active DVAs, including the stiffness and the maximum and minimum damping ratio of the subsystem, are optimized to make the peak of the displacement transmissibility curve minimum, based on the amplitude-frequency equations from approximately analytical solutions. The comparisons of the displacement transmissibility obtained from the approximate solutions and the numerical ones are fulfilled, and the results certify that the approximate solutions have satisfactory precision. At last, the statistical results of the stochastic responses of the primary systems, including the original single degree-of-freedom system, the optimally passive DVA system, and the four semi-active on-off DVA systems, are obtained when subject to random excitation. The results show that the two new semi-active DVAs presented in this paper are almost as excellent as the existing two semi-active DVAs, and all of the four semi-active DVAs have better control performance than the optimally passive DVA.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The dynamic vibration absorber (DVA), also called the tuned mass damper (TMD), is a commonly-used vibration subsystem, which is attached to a primary system to mitigate the unexpectedly transmitted force or motion to the primary system. Since its invention in the early 1900s (Frahm, 1911), the DVA had been researched extensively, and shown to be effective in much vibration control engineering, such as bridge engineering, rotating machinery and civil engineering, etc (Harris and Crede, 1976; Moheimani et al., 2003; Inman, 2006). Some researchers had made a great deal of effort to optimize the system parameters of the DVA, and the early research results were summarized in the famous textbook by Den Hartog (1956), where the focus was on the parameters design of the DVA for the primary system without viscous damping. After the 1980s, Nishihara and Asami (2002) and Asami and Nishihara (2003) researched on the parameters optimization of DVA and gave many series solutions when the primary system owns viscous damping.

As is well known, the traditional DVA is passive, where the designed parameters of DVA could not be changed when it works. In many practical applications, the inevitable variations of the parameters of the primary system (called off-tuning in some engineering fields) may cause the effectiveness of the DVA to be reduced sharply. Moreover, the off-tuning could even magnify the vibration levels of the primary system, which may lead to unexpected damage and fault. In order to overcome the problems, the active DVA was presented, where the imposed force between the DVA and the primary system could be changed momentarily according to the different design rules (Sun et al., 1995; Burdisso et al., 1998; Chen et al., 2005; Rivaz and Rohling, 2007). Although it could present much better control performance than the passive one, the active DVA had not been used widely due to higher energy consumption, more complicated structure and lower reliability, etc.

The presence of a semi-active DVA fills the gap between the passive and active DVA, which combines the best features of the passive and active one, and represents a compromise between performance improvement and simplicity of implementation.

Jalili (2002) reviewed the basic theoretical concepts for semi-active vibration control design and implementation, including semi-active vibration isolation and vibration absorption, and surveyed recent developments and control techniques for these systems. Casciati et al. (2006) presented a comprehensive summarization on the control law, control devices, implementation issues, and experimental verification of semi-active DVA. Hrovat et al. (1983) used a semi-active DVA to control wind-induced vibrations in tall buildings and found that the semi-active DVA was superior to the traditional passively controlled system and comparable to an actively controlled one. Patten et al. (1996) presented a semi-active hydraulic bridge vibration absorber to retrofit an existing bridge, and the experimental result indicated that reduction of peak amplitude could reach almost 65–70%. Abe and Igusa (1996) presented analytical research on optimal control algorithms for semi-active absorbers and found that the semi-active vibration absorbers were suitable to control the impulse response of the structure, and more effective than traditional passive vibration absorbers. Hidaka et al. (1999) applied electro-rheological fluid in a semi-active absorber of a three-story structural model, and found that the single semi-active dynamic absorber could simultaneously reduce the vibration amplitude at several frequencies. Pinkaew and Fujino (2001) applied the optimal control theory to obtain the optimal control law governing the variation of damping coefficient, and found that the semi-active DVA could suppress the vibration of the primary system in both transient and steady-state responses. Walsh and Lamancusa (1992) designed a stiffness-variable dynamic absorber to suppress the transient vibrations of rotating machines during start-up and shut-down conditions, and obtained excellent performance of vibration control. Hu and Jin (1997) and Qian and Hu (2001) presented a semi-active vibration absorber with piecewise linear elastic components and adjustable working frequency to follow the large variation of the excitation frequency, and the following experimental results certified the effectiveness of this semi-active DVA. Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) studied four kinds of semi-active DVAs numerically, including two kinds of on-off types and two kinds of continuous ones, and then substituted the magneto-rheological damper for the traditional one and verified the perfect control performance experimentally. After that Koo, Shukla and Ahmadian (2008) investigated the effects of variation of DVA parameters on the control performance and found that an increase of the off-state damping ratio may decrease the effectiveness of the semi-active DVA in reducing maximum vibration levels. In the latest comprehensive research on semi-active on-off control of floor vibrations, Diaz and Reynolds (2010) explored the use of several on-off nonlinear velocity feedback control methods when high gain and significant vibration level were present together with saturation in the control law.

However, due to the intrinsically strong nonlinearity induced by the piecewiseness and non-smoothness from the semi-active control law, the aforementioned works were mostly focused on the numerical and experimental research, to find the effectiveness and better control performance of the semi-active DVA. Except for some work on the single degree-of-freedom semi-active vibration isolation system (Shen et al., 2006; Eslaminasab et al., 2010), little work has been fulfilled on the analytical analysis of semi-active system, neither in the semi-active vibration isolation system nor in the semi-active vibration absorption system This may affect the selection of the semi-active control law and the control parameters. In this paper, the analytical research on approximate solutions and parameters optimization of four semi-active DVAs are presented. This paper is organized as follow. In Section 2, the displacement transmissibility of the primary system without a DVA and with an optimally passive DVA is obtained. That is used as a frame of reference to compare with the four semi-active DVAs. Then Section 3 presents the analytical research on the two existing semi-active on-off DVAs by Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al., (2008) through the averaging method, so that the nonlinear algebra equations about the amplitudes and phases of approximately analytical solutions are obtained. Meanwhile, two other new semi-active on-off DVAs are presented in this section, and the similar analytical investigation is also included. Moreover, the optimal parameters of the four semi-active on-off DVAs, including the stiffness, the maximum and the minimum damping ratio of the subsystem are obtained based on the approximately analytical solutions, and the comparisons of the numerical solution and the analytical one are also fulfilled in Section 4. The comparisons between the displacement transmissibility of all the systems, including the primary system without DVA, with optimally passive DVA, and with the four semi-active DVAs, are also completed in this section. Finally, in Section 5, the stochastic responses and statistical results of all the above systems are obtained when subject to the random excitation, which further illustrate the effectiveness of the four semi-active on-off DVAs.

sec.title: 2. The primary system without dynamic vibration absorber and with optimally passive dynamic vibration absorber
sec.p: In order to compare the performance of the semi-active on-off DVAs, it is necessary to present the analytical solutions of the original primary system without DVA and with the optimal passive DVA.

sec.title: 2.1. The primary system without dynamic vibration absorber
sec.p:
The primary system without the DVA is shown in Figure 1(a), that is composed of the mass m1. the stiffness coefficient k1 and the viscous damping coefficient c1. Supposing it is subject to displacement excitation xin=Cejωt, the motion equation could be established as (1)m1x··1+k1(x1-xin)+c1(x·1-x·in)=0 Figure 1.
The primary system (a) without dynamic vibration absorber, (b) with optimally passive dynamic vibration absorber, (c) with semi-active on-off dynamic vibration absorber, (d) with ideal ground-hook dynamic vibration absorber.
Supposing x1=Aej(ωt+θ), the displacement transmissibility could be obtained as (2)AC=k12+(c1ω)2(c1ω)2+(k1-m1ω2)2

sec.title: 2.2. The primary system with the optimally passive dynamic vibration absorber
sec.p: The primary system with the optimally passive DVA is shown in Figure 1(b), where the mass m2, the stiffness coefficient k2 and the viscous damping coefficient c2 are called as DVA or subsystem. Here the viscous damping coefficient c1 of the primary system is omitted. Although Nishihara and Asami (2002) and Asami and Nishihara (2003) had presented the analytical forms of the optimal parameters of the DVA when the primary system owns viscous damping, it is difficult to design a vibration absorption system in practice due to the complicated series forms of the optimal parameters. Moreover, Nishihara and Asami (2002) and Asami and Nishihara (2003) proved that the small viscous damping coefficient in the primary system had little effect on the analysis of optimal DVA. The motion equation is (3)g{m2x··2+k2(x2-x1)+c2(x·2-x·1)=0m1x··1+k1(x1-xin)+k2(x1-x2)+c2(x·1-x·2)=0

Supposing x1=Aej(ωt+θ1) and x2=Bej(ωt+θ2), and after some symbolic deduction the displacement transmissibility could be obtained (4)AC=g(2c2gccg)2+(g2-f2)2g(2c2gccg)2(g2-1+μg2)2+[μf2g2-(g2-1)(g2-f2)]2 where μ=m2/m1 is the mass ratio, ω2=k2/m2 is the natural frequency of the subsystem, ω1=k1/m1 is the natural frequency of the primary system, f=ω2/ω1 is the natural frequency ratio, g=ω/ω1 is the ratio of the excitation frequency to the natural frequency of the primary system, and cc=2m2ω1 is critical damping respectively.
According to the classical conclusions by Den Hartog (1956), and after the appropriate mass ratio μ is selected, the optimal parameters of the DVA could be obtained. g{f=11+μg(c2ccg)2=3μ8(1+μ)3g.

sec.title: 3. Approximate solutions of the semi-active on-off dynamic vibration absorbers
sec.p:
The semi-active on-off DVA is shown in Figure 1(c), where the viscous damping c2 of the subsystem is adjustable or controllable. This control law is an approximate realization of the ideal configuration of ground-hook DVA, shown in Figure 1(d). Based on the Newtonian second law, the motion equation could be established (5)g{m2x··2+c2(x·2-x·1)+k2(x2-x1)=0m1x··1+c1(x·1-x·in)+c2(x·1-x·2)+k1(x1-xin)+k2(x1-x2)=0
where xin is the displacement excitation with the form xin=bcos(ωt).

Introducing τ=ωt, ω1=k1/m1, ω2=k2/m2, xr=x1-x2, r1=ω/ω1, r2=ω/ω2, p=ω1/ω2, q=m2/m1, c1=2m1ζ1ω1, c2=2m2ζ2ω2, equation (5) could be transformed into (6)g{r22d2x1dτ2-r22d2xrdτ2-2ζ2r2dxrdτ-xr=0r1r2d2x1dτ2+2ζ1r2dx1dτ+2ζ2qr1dxrdτ+px1+qpxr =pbcosτ-2ζ1r2bsinτ where ζ1 is the damping ratio of the primary system and ζ2 is the damping ratio of the subsystem respectively. Obviously, ζ2 is adjustable along with the adopted semi-active control law.

Now the averaging method is applied (Burd 2007; Sanders et al. 2007) to obtain the approximately analytical solution of equation (6). The solution has the form as (7){x1=a1(τ)cosφ1(τ)dx1dτ=-a1(τ)sinφ1(τ) (8){xr=ar(τ)cosφr(τ)dxrdτ=-ar(τ)sinφr(τ) where φ1(τ)=τ+θ1(τ), φr(τ)=τ+θr(τ). By differentiating equation (7) and equation (8) with respect to τ, the following could be obtained (9){dx1dτ=da1dτcosφ1(τ)-a1(τ)sinφ1(τ)(1+dθ1dτ)d2x1dτ2=-[da1dτsinφ1(τ)+a1(τ)cosφ1(τ)(1+dθ1dτ)] (10){dxrdτ=dardτcosφr(τ)-ar(τ)sinφr(τ)(1+dθrdτ)d2xrdτ2=-[dardτsinφr(τ)+ar(τ)cosφr(τ)(1+dθrdτ)]

From equation (6) to equation (10), and after some symbolic deduction the next system of equations could be obtained with da1/dτ, dθ1/dτ, dar/dτ, dθr/dτ as unknown variables (11a)da1dτcosφ1-a1sinφ1dθ1dτ=0 (11b)dardτcosφr-arsinφrdθrdτ=0 (11c)da1dτsinφ1+a1cosφ1dθ1dτ=-1r1r2[pbcosτ -2ζ1r2bsinτ+2a1ζ1r2sinφ1+2arζ2r1qsinφr +a1(r1r2-p)cosφ1-qparcosφr] (11d)dardτsinφr+arcosφrdθrdτ= -1r1r2[pbcosτ-2ζ1r2bsinτ+2a1ζ1r2sinφ1 +2arr1ζ2(1+q)sinφr-pa1cosφ1 +ar(pr1r22-pr1-qr2)pr2cosφr]

Next step should be to investigate the approximate forms for the derivatives of the two amplitudes and phases, by integrating the right-hand sides of equations (12) to (15) in one period, or φi=[0 2π], i=1,r. Because the damping ratio ζ2 of the subsystem is adjustable based on the semi-active control laws, the integrating procedure must be divided into several intervals. Hence, equations (12) to (15) should be integrated based on the different semi-active control laws.

sec.title: 3.1. The approximate solution of semi-active on-off velocity-velocity based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber
sec.p: The first semi-active on-off DVA by Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al., (2008) is called as velocity based ground-hook control (VBG) DVA, which means the damping ratio ζ2 is changed according to the absolute velocity of the primary system and the relative velocity of the primary system to the subsystem. However, these semi-active control laws are called velocity-velocity based ground-hook control (VVBG) DVA in order to discriminate all the four semi-active on-off DVAs. In the semi-active on-off VVBG DVA, the controllable ζ2 is adjusted as (16)ζ2={ζmax x·1(x·1-x·2)≥0ζmin x·1(x·1-x·2)<0 where ζmax is the maximum viscous ratio corresponding to the on state, ζmin is the minimum one corresponding to the off state, x·1 is the absolute velocity of the primary system, and x·1-x·2 is the relative velocity of the primary system to the subsystem.
Due to x1=a1cos(τ+θ1) and x2=a2cos(τ+θ2), then (17)xr=x1-x2=arcos(τ+θr) where (18)ar=(a1sinθ1-a2sinθ2)2+(a1cosθ1-a2cosθ2)2θr=arctana1sinθ1-a2sinθ2a1cosθ1-a2cosθ2
For most designed DVA, it should be satisfied a2>>a1andθ2>θ1 which leads to θr≈θ2>θ1

Due to x·1=-a1sin(τ+θ1) and x·r=-arsin(τ+θr), and from the general time history of x·1 and x·r shown in Figure 2, equation (16) could be changed into (19)ζ2={ζmax-θ1<φ≤π-θrξminπ-θr<φ≤π-θ1ζmaxπ-θ1<φ≤2π-θrξmin2π-θr<φ≤2π-θ1 Figure 2.
A typical phase difference between x·1 and x·1-x·2, where the X-coordinate and Y-coordinate is the phase and amplitude of x·1 (the solid line) and x·1-x·2 (the dashed line) respectively.

According to the averaging method, the approximate solution of semi-active on-off VVBG DVA could be obtained by averaging the right-side parts of equations (12) to (15) in one period (20)da1dτ=12πpr1r2∫02π{bp[-pcos(φ1-θ1)+2r2ζ1sin(φ1-θ1)]+pa1[(p-r1r2)cosφ1-2r2ζ1sinφ1]+qar[cos(φ1+θr-θ1)+2pr1ζ2sin(φ1+θr-θ1)]}sinφ1dφ1 (21)da1dτ=12πpr1r2∫02π{bp[-pcos(φ1-θ1)+2r2ζ1sin(φ1-θ1)]+pa1[(p-r1r2)cosφ1-2r2ζ1sinφ1]+qar[cos(φ1+θr-θ1)+2pr1ζ2sin(φ1+θr-θ1)]}sinφ1dφ1 (22)dardτ=-12πpr1r22∫02π{pr2[bpcos(θr-φr)+2br2ζ1sin(θr-φr)-a1pcos(θ1-θr+φr)+2a1r2ζ1sin(θ1-θr+φr)]+ar(pr1r22-pr1-qr2)cosφr+2arpr1r2ζ2(1+q)sinφr}sinφrdφr (23)dθrdτ=-12πparr1r22∫02π{pr2[bpcos(θr-φr)+2br2ζ1sin(θr-φr)-a1pcos(θ1-θr+φr)+2a1r2ζ1sin(θ1-θr+φr)]+ar(pr1r22-pr1-qr2)cosφr+2arpr1r2ζ2(1+q)sinφr}cosφrdφr

In vibration engineering, the steady-state response is more important and meaningful. By letting da1/dτ=0, dθ1/dτ=0, dar/dτ=0 and dθr/dτ=0, a system of four nonlinear algebra equations with four unknowns could be obtained, a1, θ1, ar, θr. Based on some numerical methods for system of nonlinear algebra equations (Hildebrand, 1987; Burden and Faires, 2005), such as Newton’s method, quasi-Newton’s method, steepest descent techniques, etc., the solution of semi-active VVBG DVA could be obtained.

sec.title: 3.2. The approximate solution of semi-active on-off displacement-velocity based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber
sec.p: The second semi-active on-off DVA by Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al., (2008) is called as displacement based ground-hook control (DBG) DVA, which means the damping ratio ζ2 is changed according to the absolute displacement of the primary system and the relative velocity of the primary system to the subsystem. Here it is called displacement-velocity based ground-hook control (DVBG) in order to avoid confusion, and the control law is as (28)ζ2=g{ζmaxx1(x·1-x·2)≥0ζminx1(x·1-x·2)<0g. where ζmax is the maximum viscous ratio corresponding to the on state, ζmin is the minimum one corresponding to the off state, x1 is the absolute displacement of the primary system, and x·1-x·2 is the relative velocity of the primary system to the subsystem.
Based on the form of x1 and xr, the following can be obtained (29)ζ2=g{ζmin-θr<φ≤π2-θ1ξmaxπ2-θ1<φ≤π-θrζminπ-θr<φ≤3π2-θ1ξmax3π2-θ1<φ≤2π-θrg

Letting da1/dτ=0, dθ1/dτ=0, dar/dτ=0 and dθr/dτ=0, a similar system of nonlinear algebra equations with four unknowns could be obtained. After solving it by the numerical methods (Hildebrand, 1987; Burden and Faires, 2005), the approximately steady-state solution of semi-active DVBG DVA could be obtained.

sec.title: 3.3. The approximate solution of semi-active on-off velocity-displacement based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber
sec.p: The aforementioned semi-active of-off DVAs, namely VVBG and DVBG, are presented by Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al. (2008) where the absolute velocity and the absolute displacement of the primary system, associated with the relative velocity of the primary system to the sub-system are used. There are also two other continuous counterparts to the two types of on-off DVAs, called as continuous VBG and continuous DBG in their papers (Koo and Ahmadian, 2004, 2007; Koo et al., 2008), while it is difficult to treat by the averaging method.

Intuitionally, the relative displacement maybe substitutes for the relative velocity in the two on-off control strategies. Accordingly, two other new semi-active on-off DVAs could be established, named as velocity-displacement based ground-hook control (VDBG) DVA and displacement-displacement based ground-hook control (DDBG) DVA.
The control strategy of VDBG DVA is shown as (34)ζ2=g{ζmaxx·1(x1-x2)≥0ζminx·1(x1-x2)<0g.
Based on the form of x1 and xr, the following can also be obtained (35)ζ2=g{ζmin-θ1<φ≤π2-θrξmaxπ2-θr<φ≤π-θ1ζminπ-θ1<φ≤3π2-θrξmax3π2-θr<φ≤2π-θ1g.

Letting da1/dτ=0, dθ1/dτ=0, dar/dτ=0 and dθr/dτ=0, a system of nonlinear algebra equations with the two steady-state amplitudes and phases as four unknowns could also be obtained. After solving it numerically, the approximately steady-state solution of semi-active VDBG DVA could be obtained.

sec.title: 3.4. The approximate solution of semi-active on-off displacement-displacement based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber
sec.p: The control strategy of DDBG DVA is shown as (40)ζ2=g{ζmaxx1(x1-x2)≥0ζminx1(x1-x2)<0g. and the integrate interval for the adjustable damping ratio is (41)ζ2=g{ζmax-θ1<φ≤π2-θrξminπ2-θr<φ≤π2-θ1ζmaxπ2-θ1<φ≤3π2-θrζmin3π2-θr<φ≤3π2-θ1ξmax3π2-θ1<φ≤2π-θ1g.

Letting da1/dτ=0, dθ1/dτ=0, dar/dτ=0 and dθr/dτ=0, a system of nonlinear algebra equations with the two steady-state amplitudes and phases as four unknowns could also be obtained. After solving it by numerical methods, the approximately steady-state solution of semi-active DDBG DVA could be obtained.

sec.title: 3.5. The further illumination of the approximate solution
sec.p: Compared with the numerical research by Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al. (2008), this investigation presents the analytical results of four semi-active on-off DVAs, shown in equations (24) to (27), equations (30) to (33), equations (36) to (39), and equations (42) to (45), that could make researchers more conveniently obtain the steady-state amplitude and phase of a semi-active on-off system associated with the displacement transmissibility. This would design a much simpler and more practical semi-active DVA.

When looking for the optimal system parameters of semi-active on-off DVAs, the analytical results are also more important. In the research by Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al. (2008), the constraint equations for the system parameters are the original nonlinear differential equations. While in this research, the constraint equations could be the abovementioned systems of nonlinear algebra equations. Accordingly, the computation speed, computation reliability, and computation precision would obviously be improved.

sec.title: 4. Parameters optimization of four semi-active on-off dynamic vibration absorbers and numerical simulation
4.1. Parameters optimization of four semi-active on-off dynamic vibration absorbers
sec.p: In this subsection is researched the parameters optimization of four semi-active on-off DVAs, where the optimization objective is to find the parameters which could minimize the peak value of the displacement transmissibility of the primary system. In the work by Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al. (2008), the nonlinear ordinary differential equations, namely the motion equations, are as the constraint conditions, which may lead to time-consuming computation work and possible convergence to the illusive and/or local results. However, in this paper the nonlinear algebra equations of the steady-state amplitudes and phases are as constraint conditions, which could remarkably reduce the computation time and possibility to the illusive and local parameters.

The basic system parameters, which are originated from the papers of Koo and Ahmadian (2004, 2007) and Koo et al. (2008) are shown in Table 1. The initial values and parameter range for optimization are shown in Table 2, and the optimization results are summarized in Table 3. Table 1.
Basic system parameters
Parameter Value
Structure mass (m1) 261.05 kg
DVA mass (m2) 14.528 kg
Structure stiffness (k1) 334075 N/m
Structure damping ratio (ζ1) 0.03
DVA: dynamic vibration absorber.
Table 2.
Initial values and parameter ranges of four semi-active DVAs
Parameter Initial value Parameter range
On-state damping ratio 0.1 0.1 ≤ ζmax ≤ 0.7
Off-state damping ratio 0.01 0.01 ≤ ζmin ≤ 0.1
DVA stiffness (N/m) 10000 10000 ≤ k2 ≤ 100000
DVA: dynamic vibration absorber.
Table 3.
Optimal parameters of four kinds of semi-active DVAs
Parameters VVBG DVBG VDBG DDBG
DVA stiffness (N/m) 16500 16400 16600 16300
On-state Damping ratio 0.11 0.11 0.11 0.11
Off-state Damping ratio 0.099 0.09 0.099 0.098
DVA: dynamic vibration absorber. VVBG: velocity-velocity based ground-hook control. DVBG: displacement-velocity based ground-hook control.
VDBG: velocity-displacement based ground-hook control. DDBG: displacement-displacement based ground-hook control.

In order to illustrate the precision of approximate solution, the curves of the displacement transmissibility are presented with respect to the excitation frequency by the analytical solutions and the numerical integration, where the basic system parameters and the optimal parameters for the four semi-active DVAs are used. In the analytical researching procedure, the steady-state a1, θ1, ar, θr could be obtained by solving the system of nonlinear algebra equations under the condition a1≥0, ar≥0, 0≤θ1≤2π, 0≤θr≤2π, and get the transmissibility by a1/b. In the numerical investigation, the fourth-order Runge-Kutta method is selected to integrate the original differential equation and obtain the steady-state response by disposing the transient one. Then the peak value of the steady-state response is considered as the steady-state amplitude and the transmissibility would be obtained. The results are shown in Figures 3 to 6, for the four semi-active on-off DVAs respectively. Figure 3.
The comparison of the approximate solution with the numerical results of the semi-active on-off velocity-velocity based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber (ω1=35.78rad/s, ζ1=0.03, q=0.056, ω2=33.70rad/s, ζmax=0.11, ζmin=0.099).
Figure 4.
The comparison of the approximate solution with the numerical results of the semi-active on-off displacement-velocity based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber (ω1=35.78rad/s, ζ1=0.03, q=0.056, ω2=33.60rad/s, ζmax=0.11, ζmin=0.09). Figure 5.
The comparison of the approximate solution with the numerical results of the semi-active on-off velocity-displacement based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber (ω1=35.78rad/s, ζ1=0.03, q=0.056, ω2=33.80rad/s, ζmax=0.11, ζmin=0.099). Figure 6.
The comparison of the approximate solution with the numerical results of the semi-active on-off displacement-displacement based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber (ω1=35.78rad/s, ζ1=0.03, q=0.056, ω2=33.50rad/s, ζmax=0.11, ζmin=0.098).

From these four figures it could be found that the approximately analytical solutions have satisfactory precision, and agree well with the results by numerical integration, especially in the low-frequency and high-frequency range. In the two resonance ranges, there are some errors between the approximately analytical solution and the numerical results, which are small enough and may have little effect on the analysis and design of semi-active on-off DVAs.

sec.title: 4.2. Comparison of the response of the systems
sec.p:
In order to illustrate the performance of the four semi-active on-off DVAs, the displacement transmissibilities of the primary system without DVA, with optimally passive DVA, and with semi-active DVAs are presented by analytical solution in Figure 7, and by numerical integration in Figure 8 respectively. Figure 7.
The analytical displacement transmissibilities of the primary system in different cases.
Figure 8.
The numerical displacement transmissibilities of the primary system in different cases.

It could be concluded that the four semi-active DVAs all have better control performance than the optimally passive DVA, and could reduce the peak value of the displacement transmissibility of the primary system effectively. More specifically, the control effectiveness of the peak value is summarized in Table 4. It can be found that the decrease ratio by the optimally passive DVA is 64.56%, while the decrease ratios by the four semi-active on-off DVAs are all almost 70%. Thus, one of the four semi-active on-off DVAs in practically vibration control engineering according to the accessibility of measurement instruments and existing sensors could be arbitrarily selected. Table 4.
The peak values of the displacement transmissibilities of the primary system
Without DVA Passive DVA VVBG DVA DVBG DVA VDBG DVA DDBG DVA
Numerical solutions
5.014 5.287 4.962 5.268
Analytical solutions 16.692 6.083 4.899 4.886 5.031 4.837
Decrease ratio of numerical results (%)
69.96 68.33 70.27 68.44
Decrease ratio of analytical results (%)
64.56 70.65 70.73 69.86 71.02
DVA: dynamic vibration absorber. VVBG: velocity-velocity based ground-hook control.
DVBG: displacement-velocity based ground-hook control. VDBG: velocity-displacement based ground-hook control. DDBG: displacement-displacement based ground-hook control.

sec.title: 5. Stochastic response to random excitation
sec.p: In civil and architecture engineering, the stochastic response to random excitation may be more important, because the excitation originated from the wind or earthquake is random or has stronger randomicity. Using the given system parameters and the optimized parameters of semi-active on-off DVAs, the time histories and stochastic responses to random excitation could be obtained, and research statistical values of system response, such as variance, that is usually relevant with the system energy.

Here a 50s random excitation is constructed, which is composed of 5000 random numbers with normal distribution. Furthermore, the excitation is normalized so that it is with mean value 0 and variance 1 respectively. The time history of the random excitation is shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
The time history of random excitation.

Based on some numerical integration methods, such as fourth-order variable-step Runge-Kutta method, the stochastic responses of the original primary system could be obtained without DVA and with optimally passive DVA, and four semi-active on-off DVAs. In the numerical integrating procedure, all the systems are considered as subject to constant excitation in every small integrating interval. Because the integrating time is long enough and the integrating interval is small enough, the computation error could be omitted. The time histories of these systems are shown in Figures 10 to 15. The variances and decrease ratios are summarized in Table 5. Figure 10.
The time history of the primary system without dynamic vibration absorber.
Figure 11.
The time history of the primary system with optimally passive dynamic vibration absorber. Figure 12.
The time history of the primary system with semi-active on-off velocity-velocity based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber. Figure 13.
The time history of the primary system with semi-active on-off displacement-velocity based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber. Figure 14.
The time history of the primary system with semi-active on-off velocity-displacement based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber. Figure 15.
The time history of the primary system with semi-active on-off displacement-displacement based ground-hook control dynamic vibration absorber.
Table 5.
The variances and decrease ratios of the displacement of the primary system
Without DVA Passive DVA VVBG DVA DVBG DVA VDBG DVA DDBG DVA
Variances 2.8786 2.3424 1.0510 1.0730 1.0459 1.0592
Decrease ratio (%)
18.63 63.49 62.72 63.67 63.20
DVA: dynamic vibration absorber. VVBG: velocity-velocity based ground-hook control.
DVBG: displacement-velocity based ground-hook control. VDBG: velocity-displacement based ground-hook control. DDBG: displacement-displacement based ground-hook control.

It could be found that the four semi-active on-off DVAs all have much more improvement in control performance than the optimally passive DVA. The decrease ratio of statistical results by the optimally passive DVA is 18.63, while the decrease ratios of statistical results by the four semi-active on-off DVAs are more than 60%. Hence, the four semi-active on-off DVAs could reduce not only the peak value of the displacement transmissibility remarkably, but also the stochastic response in whole-frequency range excellently.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: Two new types of semi-active on-off DVAs are presented in this paper, and the analytically approximate solutions are obtained by the averaging method, along with the two existing semi-active on-off DVAs by other researchers. And the parameters optimizations of four semi-active on-off DVAs are completed. The comparisons of approximately analytical solutions with the numerical solution certify the satisfactory precision of the approximately analytical solutions. The response of the primary system without DVA, with optimally passive DVA, and with the four semi-active DVAs, subject to single-frequency sinusoidal excitation and random excitation, are all researched. The results show the four semi-active on-off DVA have more improvement in control performance.
